boston.name: Boston Marathon
boston.description: The Boston Marathon is one of the World Marathon Majors and features a challenging point-to-point course from Hopkinton to Boston. Known for its qualifying standards and historic significance, the course includes the famous Heartbreak Hill between miles 20-21.
tips: Train on hills - Heartbreak Hill comes at mile 20
Negative split strategy recommended due to net downhill
Weather can be unpredictable in April
Qualifying time required for entry

paceStrategy.summary: Start conservative despite downhill opening. Save energy for Newton Hills (miles 16-21), then use the final downhill miles to close strong.

segments.advice: Resist the temptation to bank time. Run 10-15 sec/mile slower than goal pace.
Settle into goal pace. Stay relaxed through Framingham and Natick.
Maintain rhythm. Wellesley College crowds will energize you at mile 13.
Run by effort, not pace. Expect to slow 15-30 sec/mile. This is where races are lost.
Stay mentally strong. Shorten stride, maintain cadence. Don't surge at the top.
Let gravity help. Pick up pace gradually. Trust your training.

boston.fuelingNotes: Take an extra gel at mile 15-16 before Newton Hills. The climbs increase energy demand significantly. Consider salt tabs if racing in warmer conditions.

faq.question: How hilly is the Boston Marathon?
faq.answer: Boston has 156m (512ft) of elevation gain, with the famous Newton Hills from miles 16-21 including Heartbreak Hill. Despite being net downhill (140m drop), the late hills make it challenging.

faq.question: Is Boston Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: Boston is harder than flat courses like Chicago or Berlin due to the Newton Hills coming when you're already fatigued. Most runners find it 2-5 minutes slower than their flat marathon potential.

faq.question: What is Heartbreak Hill?
faq.answer: Heartbreak Hill is the fourth and final hill in the Newton Hills section, located between miles 20-21. It rises about 27m (88ft) over 0.4 miles. The name comes from the 1936 race when Johnny Kelley's heart was 'broken' after being passed here.

faq.question: What pace should I run at Boston?
faq.answer: Start 10-15 seconds per mile slower than goal pace for the first 5 miles. The downhill start tempts fast early splits that you'll pay for on the Newton Hills.

nyc.name: New York City Marathon
nyc.description: The NYC Marathon takes runners through all five boroughs of New York City. Starting on Staten Island and finishing in Central Park, this course offers incredible crowd support and iconic city views throughout the 26.2-mile journey.
tips: Prepare for bridges - Verrazzano, Queensboro, Willis Ave, and Madison Ave
Crowd energy is amazing but can lead to going out too fast
Weather in November can vary greatly
Lottery system for entry - very competitive

paceStrategy.summary: Run by effort, not pace. The bridges will slow you down - don't fight them. The crowds in Brooklyn can pull you too fast. Save energy for the Queensboro Bridge and the final Central Park hills.

segments.advice: Uphill then downhill. Don't chase fast starters. Stay controlled.
Incredible crowds. Resist surging. Lock into goal pace rhythm.
Pulaski Bridge at mile 13 - small climb. Stay focused.
Long, quiet climb. No crowds. Mental challenge. Run your own race.
Crowds return on 1st Ave. Willis Ave Bridge at mile 20. Stay patient.
Rolling hills in the park. Final push. Trust your training.

nyc.fuelingNotes: Take a gel before the Queensboro Bridge (mile 14) - you'll need the energy for the quiet, mental miles on the bridge. The aid stations on the bridge are limited.

faq.question: How hard is the NYC Marathon course?
faq.answer: NYC has 234m (768ft) of elevation gain - more than Boston. The five bridges create challenging climbs, especially the long Queensboro Bridge at miles 15-16. It's not a PR course for most runners.

faq.question: Which bridge is hardest in NYC Marathon?
faq.answer: The Queensboro Bridge (miles 15-16) is the toughest mentally and physically. It's a long, gradual climb with no crowd support, and comes when you're already fatigued.

faq.question: What's the best pacing strategy for NYC?
faq.answer: Run by effort, not pace. Accept that bridges will slow you. Many runners go out too fast in Brooklyn due to crowd energy and pay for it later. Even effort is key.

faq.question: How are the crowds at NYC Marathon?
faq.answer: NYC has the best crowd support of any marathon - over 1 million spectators. The only quiet section is the Queensboro Bridge. Brooklyn and 1st Avenue are electric.

chicago.name: Chicago Marathon
chicago.description: Known as one of the fastest marathon courses in the world, the Chicago Marathon is a flat, fast loop through the city's diverse neighborhoods. The course offers incredible crowd support and showcases Chicago's architectural beauty.
tips: Perfect for a PR - extremely flat and fast course
Crowd support is exceptional throughout
October weather is usually ideal for running
Pace yourself early - it's easy to go out too fast

paceStrategy.summary: Chicago is built for even splits. The flat course and ideal October weather make it perfect for locking into goal pace from the start. Don't go out too fast - the lack of hills means no excuses.

segments.advice: Easy to go out fast. Stick to goal pace. The crowd energy in Lincoln Park is incredible.
Settle into rhythm. Boystown crowds at mile 8-9 are legendary.
Halfway point. Check in with your body. Maintain form.
This is where flat becomes mentally tough. Stay focused. Crowds thin slightly.
Dig deep. The dragons and drums in Chinatown will lift you.
Final push on Michigan Ave. Trust your training. PR awaits.

chicago.fuelingNotes: Standard fueling works well on this flat course. Take gels every 45-60 minutes. The predictable pace makes it easy to plan exact timing. Don't experiment on race day.

faq.question: Is Chicago Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: Yes! Chicago is one of the fastest courses in the world with only 89m of elevation gain. The flat terrain, great weather, and crowd support make it ideal for personal bests.

faq.question: How flat is the Chicago Marathon?
faq.answer: Chicago has just 89m (292ft) of elevation gain - essentially pancake flat. The only 'hills' are highway overpasses that feel like speed bumps.

faq.question: What's the weather like for Chicago Marathon?
faq.answer: October in Chicago typically offers ideal marathon conditions: 7-15°C (45-60°F), low humidity. Occasionally it can be warm or windy off the lake.

faq.question: How does Chicago compare to other majors?
faq.answer: Chicago is the fastest of the World Marathon Majors due to its flat course. It's easier than Boston, NYC, and Tokyo. Similar to Berlin in terms of PR potential.

london.name: London Marathon
london.description: The London Marathon follows a scenic route through the capital, passing famous landmarks including Tower Bridge, Big Ben, and Buckingham Palace. Known for incredible charity fundraising and fancy dress runners.
tips: Iconic landmarks provide natural pacing markers
Crowd support is legendary, especially at Tower Bridge
Weather can be unpredictable in April
Ballot entry system - very competitive

paceStrategy.summary: London is relatively flat with a fast finish. The crowd support is exceptional throughout. Use the landmarks as mental checkpoints and stay patient through the quieter Docklands section.

segments.advice: Three start areas merge. Don't weave. Settle into pace.
Quieter section. Stay mentally engaged. Don't zone out.
Around the skyscrapers. Crowds pick up. Halfway approaching.
Mental challenge seeing faster runners coming back. Run your race.
Tower Bridge is iconic and loud. Use the energy. Big Ben ahead.
Buckingham Palace finish. Dig deep. Crowds are incredible.

london.fuelingNotes: Fuel well before mile 18 - the final stretch along the Embankment and The Mall is fast and you'll want full energy for the iconic finish. UK gels at aid stations may differ from US brands.

faq.question: Is the London Marathon flat?
faq.answer: London has 145m of elevation gain - relatively flat but not as flat as Chicago or Berlin. The course is gentle with no major hills, making it suitable for PRs.

faq.question: What landmarks do you pass in London Marathon?
faq.answer: You'll pass the Cutty Sark, Tower Bridge, the Tower of London, Big Ben, the Houses of Parliament, and finish on The Mall in front of Buckingham Palace.

faq.question: How hard is it to get into London Marathon?
faq.answer: Very competitive. The ballot has over 500,000 applicants for about 50,000 spots. Charity places, Good for Age times, and Championship entries offer other routes in.

faq.question: What's the weather like for London Marathon?
faq.answer: April weather is unpredictable: typically 8-15°C (46-59°F) but can range from cold rain to unexpected warmth. Layer up for the start and prepare for anything.

berlin.name: Berlin Marathon
berlin.description: The Berlin Marathon is known as the fastest course in the world, where most world records have been set. The flat, fast route passes through the Brandenburg Gate and showcases the city's rich history.
tips: World's fastest course - perfect for PBs
September weather is usually ideal
Incredible organization and crowd support
Brandenburg Gate finish is iconic

paceStrategy.summary: Berlin is THE course for even splits and world records. Lock into goal pace from kilometer 1 and don't deviate. The flat terrain and September weather create perfect conditions.

segments.advice: Start near the Victory Column. Large field - don't weave. Lock into pace immediately.
Through former East Berlin. Consistent pace. Soak in the history.
Halfway point. Check your splits. You should be on exact pace.
The 'business district' of the race. No surprises. Execute the plan.
Final 10K. If you've run smart, you have energy to push.
Unter den Linden to the Gate. One of the greatest finishes in running. Enjoy it.

berlin.fuelingNotes: Perfect course for precise fueling. With virtually no elevation change, your energy expenditure is predictable. Stick to your practiced plan - this is not the race to experiment.

faq.question: Why is Berlin the fastest marathon?
faq.answer: Berlin has just 67m of elevation gain - the flattest World Major. Combined with ideal September weather (12-18°C), wide roads, and great organization, it has hosted more world records than any other course.

faq.question: How many world records have been set at Berlin?
faq.answer: Berlin has hosted 11 world records, including Eliud Kipchoge's 2:01:09 in 2022 and Tigist Assefa's women's record of 2:11:53 in 2023.

faq.question: What's the best strategy for Berlin Marathon?
faq.answer: Even pace from start to finish. The flat course rewards consistent running. Pick your goal pace, lock in, and execute. Don't go out fast hoping to 'bank time.'

faq.question: How does Berlin compare to Chicago for a PR?
faq.answer: Both are excellent PR courses. Berlin is slightly flatter (67m vs 89m gain) and has more world records. Chicago has better crowd support. Weather is similar in September/October.

tokyo.name: Tokyo Marathon
tokyo.description: The Tokyo Marathon showcases Japan's capital from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building to the Imperial Palace. Known for exceptional organization, enthusiastic crowds, and unique cultural experience.
tips: Impeccable organization and crowd support
March weather is generally favorable
Cultural experience unlike any other marathon
Lottery system with very low acceptance rate

paceStrategy.summary: Tokyo starts with more climbing and finishes flatter. The net uphill profile favors a conservative start. The polite, organized crowds provide steady support throughout.

segments.advice: Start conservative. The crowds are enthusiastic but polite. Find your rhythm.
Pass the Imperial Palace. Enjoy the scenery. Stay patient.
Shopping district. Crowds thick. Halfway point - assess how you feel.
Can be mentally challenging. You'll see elite runners returning. Stay focused.
Course flattens. If you ran smart, you can push now.
Finish near Tokyo Station. Soak in the accomplishment.

tokyo.fuelingNotes: Japanese aid stations are impeccable but may have unfamiliar products. Bring your own gels. Aid stations offer rice balls and miso soup later in the race - an acquired taste during a marathon!

faq.question: How hard is Tokyo Marathon to get into?
faq.answer: Extremely competitive. The lottery has over 300,000 applicants for about 38,000 spots - roughly 12% acceptance rate. Charity and tour packages offer guaranteed entry.

faq.question: Is Tokyo Marathon a fast course?
faq.answer: Tokyo has 198m of elevation gain - more than Chicago or Berlin but still runnable for PRs. The net uphill makes it slightly harder than the flattest majors.

faq.question: What makes Tokyo Marathon special?
faq.answer: The organization is legendary - everything runs like clockwork. Spectators bow and cheer politely. Aid stations offer unique Japanese snacks. It's a cultural experience beyond just a race.

faq.question: What's the weather like for Tokyo Marathon?
faq.answer: Early March typically offers 5-12°C (41-54°F) with low humidity. Occasionally cold rain. Generally good marathon weather but bring layers for the start.

sydney.name: Sydney Marathon
sydney.description: The Sydney Marathon offers stunning harbor views, crossing the iconic Harbour Bridge and passing the Opera House. Recently elevated to World Marathon Major status, featuring Australia's most scenic marathon course.
tips: Harbour Bridge crossing is a highlight and challenge
Spring weather in September is ideal
Stunning harbor views throughout the course
Recently became a World Marathon Major - growing prestige

paceStrategy.summary: Sydney front-loads its climbing with the Harbour Bridge in the first 10K. Start conservative, tackle the bridge patiently, then use the flatter back half to make up time.

segments.advice: Significant climb early. Don't fight it. Run by effort.
Iconic crossing. Enjoy the view. Control your descent.
Undulating terrain. Stay patient. Opera House views ahead.
Some hills remain. Halfway done with climbing. Maintain effort.
Flatter section. Time to settle and push if feeling good.
Downhill finish to the Opera House. Let gravity help. Iconic end.

sydney.fuelingNotes: Front-load your fueling given the early climbs. Take your first gel earlier than usual (mile 4-5) before the Harbour Bridge effort depletes your stores. The net downhill finish means less fuel needed late.

faq.question: Is Sydney Marathon a World Major?
faq.answer: Yes! Sydney became the 7th World Marathon Major in 2025, joining Boston, NYC, Chicago, London, Berlin, and Tokyo. It's the first major in the Southern Hemisphere.

faq.question: How hilly is Sydney Marathon?
faq.answer: Sydney has 234m of elevation gain - the hilliest World Major. The Harbour Bridge crossing in the first 10K is the main challenge. The course is net downhill overall.

faq.question: When is the best time to run Sydney Marathon?
faq.answer: The race is in August/September, which is early spring in Australia. Temperatures are typically 10-18°C (50-64°F) - ideal marathon weather.

faq.question: What landmarks do you pass in Sydney Marathon?
faq.answer: You cross the iconic Harbour Bridge, run past the Sydney Opera House, through the Royal Botanic Gardens, Centennial Park, and finish with harbor views.

paris.name: Paris Marathon
paris.description: The Paris Marathon is one of the world's most scenic marathons, starting on the Champs-Élysées and finishing near the Arc de Triomphe. The course passes iconic landmarks including the Louvre, Place de la Bastille, and the Bois de Vincennes.
tips: Start at Champs-Élysées is electric - don't go out too fast
Cobblestones in some sections require careful footing
Bois de Vincennes (miles 8-15) can feel lonely after city crowds
Fast finish downhill toward Arc de Triomphe

paceStrategy.summary: Paris is relatively flat with a few gentle climbs. The course suits even pacing, but watch out for cobblestones and the quieter stretch through the parks.

segments.advice: Iconic start. Huge crowds. Don't get caught up in the excitement.
Park section. Crowds thin. Stay mentally engaged.
Back in the city. Crowds return. Check your splits.
Beautiful scenery. Some cobblestones. Stay patient.
Final park. Dig deep. Finish approaching.

segments.terrain: Avenue Foch to Arc de Triomphe
segments.advice: Fast downhill finish. Give it everything.

paris.fuelingNotes: French aid stations have excellent variety but may differ from what you've practiced with. Bring your own gels. The park sections (Vincennes, Boulogne) have consistent aid stations.

faq.question: Is the Paris Marathon a good PR course?
faq.answer: Yes, Paris is relatively flat (135m gain) and can produce fast times. The cobblestone sections require some caution, but overall it's comparable to London for speed.

faq.question: What landmarks do you pass in the Paris Marathon?
faq.answer: You'll start at the Champs-Élysées, pass the Louvre, Place de la Bastille, run through Bois de Vincennes and Bois de Boulogne, along the Seine, and finish near the Arc de Triomphe.

faq.question: What's the weather like for Paris Marathon?
faq.answer: April weather is variable: typically 8-16°C (46-61°F). Can be chilly at the start and warm by finish. Prepare for potential rain.

faq.question: How hard is it to get into Paris Marathon?
faq.answer: Easier than London or Tokyo. Registration typically opens in the fall and sells out in days to weeks. No lottery - first come, first served.

amsterdam.name: Amsterdam Marathon
amsterdam.description: The TCS Amsterdam Marathon is one of the flattest marathons in the world, starting and finishing at the Olympic Stadium. Known for fast times, the course loops through the city and along the Amstel River.
tips: One of the flattest courses in the world - perfect for PRs
Start and finish at historic 1928 Olympic Stadium
October weather is usually ideal but can be windy
Loop course means you can use the Olympic Stadium for warm-up

paceStrategy.summary: Amsterdam is pancake flat - one of the flattest in the world. Lock into goal pace and execute. Watch for wind along the Amstel River.

segments.advice: Start in the historic stadium. Find your pace group early.
Through Amsterdam's canals. Consistent footing. Lock in.
Out and back along the river. Can be exposed to wind. Draft if possible.
Heading back. Check your splits. Execute the plan.
Finish on the stadium track. Iconic ending. Push to the line.

amsterdam.fuelingNotes: The flat course makes pacing and fueling predictable. Stick to your practiced plan. Wind along the river can increase energy expenditure - account for this.

faq.question: How flat is the Amsterdam Marathon?
faq.answer: Amsterdam has just 25m (82ft) of elevation gain - it's essentially sea level flat. One of the 5 flattest major marathons in the world.

faq.question: Is Amsterdam good for a PR?
faq.answer: Excellent! The flat course, moderate October weather, and fast pack running make Amsterdam one of the best PR courses. Many runners set personal bests here.

faq.question: What's unique about Amsterdam Marathon?
faq.answer: The start and finish in the 1928 Olympic Stadium is iconic. You finish running on the track where athletes competed nearly 100 years ago.

faq.question: How does Amsterdam compare to Berlin?
faq.answer: Both are fast and flat. Berlin has slightly more prestige and more world records, but Amsterdam is equally fast and easier to enter.

valencia.name: Valencia Marathon
valencia.description: The Valencia Marathon Trinidad Alfonso is known as the 'World's Fastest City' due to its exceptional flat course, ideal December weather, and fast times. The course passes the futuristic City of Arts and Sciences.
tips: Self-proclaimed 'World's Fastest City' - justifiably so
December weather is nearly perfect for marathons
City of Arts and Sciences provides stunning backdrop
Fast flat course with excellent crowd support

paceStrategy.summary: Valencia's flat course and perfect December weather make it ideal for even pacing and PRs. This is a course built for speed.

segments.advice: Start controlled. Great atmosphere but don't go out too fast.
Through residential areas. Settle into rhythm.
Along the old Turia riverbed. Beautiful and fast.
Stunning modern architecture. Stay focused despite scenery.
Fast finish. If you ran smart, you can PR here.

valencia.fuelingNotes: Perfect conditions for precise fueling. The predictable flat terrain means consistent energy expenditure. Follow your practiced plan exactly.

faq.question: Why is Valencia called the fastest marathon?
faq.answer: Valencia has produced numerous national records and personal bests. The combination of flat course (28m gain), ideal December weather (10-15°C), and organized pacers creates perfect PR conditions.

faq.question: How does Valencia compare to Berlin for a PR?
faq.answer: Valencia is arguably better for PRs - it's flatter (28m vs 67m), has better weather (December vs September), and has less crowding. Many elite runners choose Valencia for record attempts.

faq.question: What's the weather like in Valencia in December?
faq.answer: December offers near-perfect marathon conditions: 8-15°C (46-59°F), low humidity, minimal wind. Rarely hot, occasionally chilly at the start.

faq.question: How hard is it to get into Valencia Marathon?
faq.answer: Moderately competitive. Registration opens in spring and sells out within months. Faster than Tokyo/London, slower than Chicago.

rotterdam.name: Rotterdam Marathon
rotterdam.description: The NN Marathon Rotterdam is famous for fast times and has hosted multiple world records. The flat course through modern Rotterdam showcases the city's innovative architecture.
tips: Historic fast course - multiple world records set here
April weather can be variable but often good
Modern city architecture provides unique scenery
Strong elite field attracts fast amateur runners

paceStrategy.summary: Rotterdam is one of the original 'fast marathons' - flat and designed for speed. The spring date means variable weather, so adjust if needed.

segments.advice: Start among Rotterdam's modern skyscrapers. Don't go out too fast.
Through quieter areas. Maintain rhythm.
Along the Maas River. Potential wind exposure.
Heading back toward finish. Dig deep.
Iconic finish on Coolsingel boulevard. Give it everything.

rotterdam.fuelingNotes: Flat course allows precise fueling. Watch for wind from the river - it can increase energy needs. Dutch aid stations are well-organized.

faq.question: Is Rotterdam a fast marathon?
faq.answer: Yes! Rotterdam has hosted world records and is one of Europe's fastest marathons. The flat course (35m gain) and strong elite field create fast conditions.

faq.question: How does Rotterdam compare to Amsterdam?
faq.answer: Both are extremely flat Dutch marathons. Rotterdam (April) typically has better elite depth; Amsterdam (October) often has better weather. Both produce PRs.

faq.question: What's the weather like for Rotterdam Marathon?
faq.answer: April brings variable conditions: typically 8-15°C (46-59°F), but can range from cold rain to warm sun. Check the forecast race week.

faq.question: Why do elites choose Rotterdam?
faq.answer: The flat course, strong organization, and history of fast times attract top runners. The prize money and pacemaker setup are excellent.

marine-corps.name: Marine Corps Marathon
marine-corps.description: Known as 'The People's Marathon,' the Marine Corps Marathon is one of the largest marathons in the US with no prize money. The course passes iconic DC monuments including the Pentagon, National Mall, and finishes at the Iwo Jima Memorial.
tips: No prize money - truly 'The People's Marathon'
Marines hand out medals at the finish line
Course passes all major DC monuments
Beat the Bridge cutoff at mile 17 (Bridge closes at 1:55 pm)

paceStrategy.summary: MCM has several notable hills, including climbs on the National Mall. Start conservative and save energy for the hills in miles 20-24.

segments.advice: Start at the Pentagon. Don't go out too fast on the rolling terrain.
Through Arlington and into Georgetown. Some early hills.
Out and back on the peninsula. Can be windy and mentally challenging.
Past the monuments. Beat the Bridge cutoff at mile 17.
Several climbs. This is where the race gets hard.
Final push to Iwo Jima Memorial. Marines are waiting.

marine-corps.fuelingNotes: The hills in the second half increase energy needs. Take an extra gel before mile 18. Marines at aid stations are exceptionally encouraging.

faq.question: Why is MCM called the People's Marathon?
faq.answer: MCM has no prize money - elite and amateur runners compete on equal footing. It's run by the Marine Corps for runners of all abilities.

faq.question: How hilly is the Marine Corps Marathon?
faq.answer: MCM has 245m (804ft) of elevation gain - hillier than NYC. Notable climbs in the first half and challenging hills miles 20-24.

faq.question: What is Beat the Bridge?
faq.answer: Runners must cross the 14th Street Bridge by mile 17 before the 1:55 PM cutoff (about 4:15 pace from gun time). Slower runners should start early in their corral.

faq.question: Who hands out medals at MCM?
faq.answer: Marines personally place finisher medals around each runner's neck - a unique and emotional experience that makes MCM special.

big-sur.name: Big Sur Marathon
big-sur.description: Often called 'The Outdoor Beautiful' the Big Sur International Marathon runs along the stunning Pacific Coast Highway. Known for incredible scenery, challenging hills including Hurricane Point, and the famous pianist on Bixby Bridge.
tips: Not a PR course - run for the experience
Hurricane Point (miles 10-12) is brutal but beautiful
A pianist plays on Bixby Bridge - don't miss it
Point-to-point with bus to start - dress warm for early morning

paceStrategy.summary: Big Sur is about the experience, not the time. Run by effort, not pace. Hurricane Point will humble you, but the scenery makes it worth it.

segments.advice: Start in Big Sur. Don't bank time - save legs for the climbs.
Pacific Ocean views. Enjoy the scenery. Stay conservative.
The big one: 520ft climb over 2 miles. Walk if needed. This is the race.
Listen for the piano. Incredible views. Control your descent.
Smaller hills remain. Legs are tired. Keep moving.
Downhill finish to the beach. Celebrate completing one of the world's most beautiful marathons.

big-sur.fuelingNotes: The hills increase energy needs significantly. Bring extra fuel. Aid stations are well-stocked but spread out. The ocean air and wind can be dehydrating.

faq.question: Is Big Sur Marathon good for a PR?
faq.answer: No. With 610m (2,000ft) of elevation gain including Hurricane Point, Big Sur is one of the hardest major marathons. Run it for the experience, not the time.

faq.question: What is Hurricane Point?
faq.answer: Hurricane Point is a brutal climb from miles 10-12, gaining 520ft (158m) over 2 miles. It's the defining challenge of Big Sur and offers incredible Pacific views.

faq.question: Why is there a pianist on the bridge?
faq.answer: Since 1987, a grand piano has been placed on Bixby Bridge at mile 13. A tuxedo-clad pianist plays as runners cross - it's become an iconic Big Sur tradition.

faq.question: How do I get to the start?
faq.answer: Big Sur is point-to-point. Buses transport runners from the finish area to the start in Big Sur. It's an early morning (4 AM) cold bus ride - bring throw-away warm clothes.

california-international.name: California International Marathon
california-international.description: CIM is known as one of the fastest courses in America, featuring a net downhill profile from Folsom to Sacramento. Popular for Boston qualifying attempts and PRs.
tips: Net downhill course - excellent for BQ attempts and PRs
December weather is usually cool and ideal
Point-to-point: don't let the downhill start fool you
Large pace groups for Boston qualifying times

paceStrategy.summary: CIM's net downhill is a gift, but you must respect it. Don't go out too fast in the first half - the quads-destroying downhill can catch up to you.

segments.advice: Rolling start in Folsom. Resist going fast. Save your quads.
Steady descent. This is where people blow up by going too fast.
Course flattens as you approach Sacramento. Assess your legs.
Through Sacramento neighborhoods. The downhill advantage is over.
Finish at the State Capitol. If you ran smart, you'll PR here.

california-international.fuelingNotes: The downhill profile changes muscle recruitment - quads take a beating. Standard fueling works but your legs may tire differently than a flat course.

faq.question: Is CIM good for Boston qualifying?
faq.answer: Yes! CIM is one of the most popular BQ courses. The net downhill (107m drop), December weather, and large pace groups make it ideal for qualifying attempts.

faq.question: How much downhill is CIM?
faq.answer: CIM has a net elevation drop of 107m (340ft) from Folsom to Sacramento. It's gradual enough to not destroy your quads if you run smart.

faq.question: Is CIM harder than it looks?
faq.answer: Yes. Many runners go out too fast on the downhill start and pay for it in the second half. Run even effort, not even pace, especially in miles 1-12.

faq.question: What's the weather like at CIM?
faq.answer: December in Sacramento is usually cool: 4-12°C (40-54°F). Can be foggy at the start. Generally excellent marathon conditions.

oslo.name: Oslo Marathon
oslo.description: The Oslo Marathon showcases Norway's capital with a city-center course that weaves through historic streets, modern waterfront paths, and lively spectator zones near the Oslofjord.
tips: Expect variable weather: cool air and wind off the fjord are common
Run by effort on short rollers instead of forcing even splits
Use crowds in the city center to stay relaxed early
Practice fueling in cool conditions; you may drink less than usual

paceStrategy.summary: Treat Oslo as a steady-effort race. Short rollers and wind exposure can disrupt rhythm, so stay controlled early and aim to finish strong over the final 10K.

segments.advice: Start relaxed and let the pack settle. Avoid weaving and pace surges in narrow sections.
If it's windy, tuck behind groups and run by effort, not pace.
Accept small pace fluctuations on short climbs. Keep cadence steady.
Stay patient and fuel on schedule. This is where discipline matters most.
If you've stayed controlled, gradually press the pace and use the crowds to close strong.

oslo.fuelingNotes: Cool Scandinavian weather can mute thirst. Set a simple reminder-based fueling plan (for example, every 25-30 minutes) so you stay ahead of energy needs even if you don't feel thirsty.

faq.question: Is the Oslo Marathon course flat?
faq.answer: It's best described as gently rolling. There are no massive climbs, but frequent small rises and wind exposure can add up over 42.2 km.

faq.question: What weather should I expect in Oslo?
faq.answer: Oslo often delivers cool temperatures and occasional wind, especially near the waterfront. Dress in layers you can adjust just before the start.

faq.question: Should I run even splits in Oslo?
faq.answer: Aim for even effort rather than perfectly even splits. Short rollers and wind can make strict pace targets misleading in the moment.
